# The Wizarding World of Harry Potter (Universal Orlando Resort)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The Wizarding World of Harry Potter  
---  
[![Wizarding World of Harry Potter
logo.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/5/5c/Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_logo.png)](/wiki/File:Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_logo.png)

**The Wizarding World of Harry Potter** is a themed area spanning two [theme
parks](/wiki/Theme_park "Theme park")—[Islands of
Adventure](/wiki/Islands_of_Adventure "Islands of Adventure") and [Universal
Studios Florida](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Florida "Universal Studios
Florida")—at the [Universal Orlando Resort](/wiki/Universal_Orlando_Resort
"Universal Orlando Resort") in [Orlando, Florida](/wiki/Orlando,_Florida
"Orlando, Florida"). The area is themed to the _[Harry
Potter](/wiki/Harry_Potter "Harry Potter")_ media franchise, adapting elements
from the [film series](/wiki/Harry_Potter_\(film_series\) "Harry Potter \(film
series\)") and novels by [J. K. Rowling](/wiki/J._K._Rowling "J. K. Rowling").
The attraction was designed by [Universal Creative](/wiki/Universal_Creative
"Universal Creative") from an exclusive [license](/wiki/License "License")
with [Warner Bros. Entertainment](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Entertainment "Warner
Bros. Entertainment").

The first phase was officially announced for Islands of Adventure on May 31,
2007,[10][11] and after a two-and-a-half-year construction period, the area
officially opened to the public on June 18, 2010.[2][12] The area's flagship
attraction is [Harry Potter and the Forbidden
Journey](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Forbidden_Journey "Harry Potter and the
Forbidden Journey"), which exists within a re-creation of [Hogwarts School of
Witchcraft and Wizardry](/wiki/Hogwarts "Hogwarts"). It takes riders on a
journey through [Harry Potter's](/wiki/Harry_Potter_\(character\) "Harry
Potter \(character\)") wizarding world.[13] Other attractions include [Dragon
Challenge](/wiki/Dragon_Challenge "Dragon Challenge"), a now-closed pair of
[inverted roller coasters](/wiki/Inverted_roller_coasters "Inverted roller
coasters"), and [Flight of the Hippogriff](/wiki/Flight_of_the_Hippogriff
"Flight of the Hippogriff"), a [family roller
coaster](/wiki/Family_roller_coaster "Family roller coaster"). The area also
features a re-creation of [Hogsmeade](/wiki/Hogsmeade "Hogsmeade") containing
many gift shops and restaurants from the novels including Dervish and Banges,
Honeydukes, Ollivanders, Zonko's Joke Shop (though it houses Honeydukes), the
Three Broomsticks, and the Hog's Head.

The second phase was initially announced on December 6, 2011, as a significant
expansion of the existing Wizarding World of Harry Potter. On May 8, 2013, it
was officially announced that a substantial portion of phase two would be
constructed in the adjacent Universal Studios Florida theme park with a [full
scale working replica of the Hogwarts
Express](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\) "Hogwarts Express
\(Universal Orlando Resort\)") taking guests between the two lands. This
phase's flagship attraction is [Harry Potter and the Escape from
Gringotts](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Escape_from_Gringotts "Harry Potter and
the Escape from Gringotts"), a 3D dark ride/simulator based on [Gringotts
Bank](/wiki/Gringotts_Bank "Gringotts Bank"), the wizarding bank that appears
in the book and film series. The attraction's design is similar to
[Transformers: The Ride](/wiki/Transformers:_The_Ride "Transformers: The
Ride") and the [Amazing Adventures of Spider-
Man](/wiki/The_Amazing_Adventures_of_Spider-Man "The Amazing Adventures of
Spider-Man") rides but built on a roller coaster track. The remaining
attractions are themed around London and [Diagon Alley](/wiki/Diagon_Alley
"Diagon Alley"). Diagon Alley officially opened on July 8, 2014.[6][7][8]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

### Previous attraction
attempts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Previous attraction attempts")]

A _Harry Potter_ themed attraction at a Universal Studios park or a [Disney
park](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Parks_and_Resorts "Walt Disney Parks and Resorts") was
rumored in 2003.[14][15] However, the rights to the _Harry Potter_ franchise
had been acquired by [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros."), who
denied all the rumors.[16] In 2001, Time Warner used this license to construct
and operate the [Harry Potter Movie Magic
Experience](/wiki/Harry_Potter_Movie_Magic_Experience "Harry Potter Movie
Magic Experience") at [Warner Bros. Movie
World](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Movie_World "Warner Bros. Movie World") on the [Gold
Coast](/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Queensland "Gold Coast, Queensland"), Australia. The
attraction was a small indoor walkthrough featuring many re-creations of
locations in the first two movies. After two years of operation this
attraction was removed.[17][18]

[The Walt Disney Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney
Company") and Universal entered bidding negotiations with Warner Bros. and
Rowling for the theme park rights to _Harry Potter_ in the United States.[19]
In 2004, Rowling signed a [letter-of-intent](/wiki/Letter_of_intent "Letter of
intent") with Disney, with the company intending to develop a _Harry Potter_
section within the [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic Kingdom") park
at [Walt Disney World](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World "Walt Disney World").[20]
Ultimately, Disney pulled out of negotiations, citing that Rowling's creative
influence and the terms established by Warner Bros. was too stringent.[21]

### Rumors and official
announcement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Rumors and official announcement")]

In January 2007, [About.com](/wiki/About.com "About.com") reported a rumor
from a "highly credible source" that the [Lost
Continent](/wiki/Islands_of_Adventure#The_Lost_Continent "Islands of
Adventure") area within Universal's [Islands of
Adventure](/wiki/Islands_of_Adventure "Islands of Adventure") park was to be
re-themed "to the stories and characters of one of the most popular children's
franchises".[22] Other sources followed up in the next few days with
unofficial confirmation the new area would involve _Harry Potter_ , and was
being developed under the name "Project Strong Arm" in reference to the
[KUKA](/wiki/KUKA "KUKA") robotic arm technology it would utilise.[23][24]
[Nikki Finke](/wiki/Nikki_Finke "Nikki Finke") reported her own confirmation
of the _Potter_ park plans in April,[25] followed shortly by a story in _[The
Scotsman](/wiki/The_Scotsman "The Scotsman")_ ;[26] both reports were widely
relayed by other media sources.[27][28][29] On May 31, 2007, Universal (in
partnership with [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.")) officially
announced the 20-acre (8.1 ha) addition recreating Hogwarts, the [Forbidden
Forest](/wiki/Hogwarts#Forbidden_Forest "Hogwarts") and
[Hogsmeade](/wiki/Hogsmeade "Hogsmeade"), with a planned opening in
2009.[9][10][11][30]

### Phase 1: Islands of
Adventure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Phase 1: Islands of Adventure")]

[![Themed billboards were located around the Wizarding World during the two-
year construction
period.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Wizarding_World_Under_Construction.jpg/170px-
Wizarding_World_Under_Construction.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wizarding_World_Under_Construction.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wizarding_World_Under_Construction.jpg "Enlarge")

Themed billboards were located around the Wizarding World during the two-year
construction period.

Construction of the Wizarding World of Harry Potter began seven months after
the official announcement, in January 2008. By July, the [Flying
Unicorn](/wiki/Flying_Unicorn "Flying Unicorn") and Enchanted Oak Tavern were
closed. The Flying Unicorn then began an almost two-year refurbishment which
transformed it into the [Flight of the
Hippogriff](/wiki/Flight_of_the_Hippogriff "Flight of the Hippogriff"). The
Enchanted Oak Tavern was later demolished. A bridge was built to connect The
Lost Continent with [Jurassic Park](/wiki/Islands_of_adventure#Jurassic_Park
"Islands of adventure") allowing guests to avoid the construction zone that
was to become the Wizarding World. Construction progressed with the Hogwarts
Castle slowly taking shape. By September 2008, the Dueling Dragons entrance
was moved to Jurassic Park to make room for construction of Hogsmeade. One
month later, the old entrance was demolished. By September 2009, the top shell
of Hogwarts Castle was completed. On September 15, an announcement was made
detailing what was going to be included in the Wizarding World. In early 2010,
Universal increased its marketing of the area, which included newspaper
advertisements, billboards and television commercials. The [Dueling
Dragons](/wiki/Dueling_Dragons "Dueling Dragons") were closed for some
maintenance before being transformed into the [Dragon
Challenge](/wiki/Dragon_Challenge "Dragon Challenge").[31] Construction was
completed by June 1, 2010, when the area began soft openings.[3]

A [soft opening](/wiki/Soft_opening "Soft opening") weekend was held for the
media and reserved guests, starting on May 28, 2010. The park had two opening
ceremonies that took place on June 16 and on June 18, 2010. The Wizarding
World of Harry Potter's grand opening ceremony took place on June 16 with book
series author [J. K. Rowling](/wiki/J._K._Rowling "J. K. Rowling"), and film
series actors [Daniel Radcliffe](/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe "Daniel Radcliffe"),
[Rupert Grint](/wiki/Rupert_Grint "Rupert Grint"), [Emma
Watson](/wiki/Emma_Watson "Emma Watson"), [Michael
Gambon](/wiki/Michael_Gambon "Michael Gambon"), [Robbie
Coltrane](/wiki/Robbie_Coltrane "Robbie Coltrane"), [Tom
Felton](/wiki/Tom_Felton "Tom Felton"), [Matthew
Lewis](/wiki/Matthew_Lewis_\(actor\) "Matthew Lewis \(actor\)"), [James and
Oliver Phelps](/wiki/James_and_Oliver_Phelps "James and Oliver Phelps") and
[Bonnie Wright](/wiki/Bonnie_Wright "Bonnie Wright"), as well as [Universal
Orlando Resort](/wiki/Universal_Orlando_Resort "Universal Orlando Resort")
officials, and representatives from the media. The ceremony, which was
produced by Universal Orlando Events Production in conjunction with [Thinkwell
Group](/wiki/Thinkwell_Group "Thinkwell Group"),[32] concluded with a
fireworks display and a performance by the [Orlando Philharmonic
Orchestra](/wiki/Orlando_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Orlando Philharmonic
Orchestra"), conducted by original series' composer [John
Williams](/wiki/John_Williams "John Williams"). On June 18, the second
ceremony took place, which officially opened the Wizarding World of Harry
Potter to the public. [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC")'s _[Today
Show](/wiki/Today_\(NBC_program\) "Today \(NBC program\)")_[33] and [The
Weather Channel](/wiki/The_Weather_Channel "The Weather Channel") broadcast
segments live from the park.[34][35][36]

### Phase 2: Universal Studios
Florida[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Phase 2: Universal Studios Florida")]

The opening of the Wizarding World of Harry Potter saw attendance at Islands
of Adventure rise by as much as 36% in 2010. According to Jason Garcia of the
_[Orlando Sentinel](/wiki/Orlando_Sentinel "Orlando Sentinel")_ , this had
resort executives pondering "when to expand Wizarding World and how to keep
business balanced between Islands and [Universal Studios
Florida](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Florida "Universal Studios Florida")".[37] In
April 2011, Brady MacDonald of the _[Los Angeles
Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ speculated that an
expansion of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter would see attractions such as
[Diagon Alley](/wiki/Diagon_Alley "Diagon Alley") and a
[Gringotts](/wiki/Gringotts "Gringotts")-themed dark ride replace Islands of
Adventure's Lost Continent themed area.[38]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Jaws_ride_closed_2.jpg/220px-
Jaws_ride_closed_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jaws_ride_closed_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jaws_ride_closed_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Demolition of the Jaws ride and the surrounding Amity in March 2012

On December 6, 2011, Universal Parks & Resorts announced that they would be
expanding The Wizarding World of Harry Potter. The expansion was described as
"significant" by officials; however, no further details were released at the
time.[39][40] The announcement came just four days after Universal Studios
Florida announced the closure of the park's [Jaws](/wiki/Jaws_\(ride\) "Jaws
\(ride\)") attraction and surrounding Amity area on January 2, 2012.[41] On
January 25, 2012, the _Los Angeles Times_ stated that the site of the former
Jaws attraction would be used for The Wizarding World of Harry Potter
expansion. These attractions would be complemented by a replica of the
[Hogwarts Express](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express "Hogwarts Express") to move guests
between the two parks.[42] Demolition of the Jaws attraction and the Amity
area began almost immediately after their closure.[43][44] After the site was
leveled, work began on [land reclamation](/wiki/Land_reclamation "Land
reclamation") in the area's former lagoon, as well as construction of a series
of buildings including a large [show building](/wiki/Show_building "Show
building").[45][46][47]

Further details about the expansion of the Wizarding World of Harry Potter
were announced on May 8, 2013. Officials confirmed that the expansion would be
set predominantly in the adjacent Universal Studios Florida theme park, and
would feature attractions themed after Diagon Alley and London. The rumored
Hogwarts Express connection between the two parks was also confirmed.
Officials stated the expansion should open in 2014.[48][49][50][51]

On January 23, 2014, officials announced the name of the flagship attraction
would be [Harry Potter and the Escape from
Gringotts](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Escape_from_Gringotts "Harry Potter and
the Escape from Gringotts"). They also indicated that a two-park pass would be
necessary to ride the [Hogwarts
Express](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\) "Hogwarts Express
\(Universal Orlando Resort\)"), which was set to connect Universal Studios
Florida with the existing Harry Potter attraction at Universal's Islands of
Adventure.[52][53][54]

The official opening date of the Diagon Alley phase was announced at an
exclusive and private press conference on June 17, 2014, for July 8, 2014. On
June 18, 2014, the Diagon Alley red carpet premiere took place with [Domhnall
Gleeson](/wiki/Domhnall_Gleeson "Domhnall Gleeson"), [Bonnie
Wright](/wiki/Bonnie_Wright "Bonnie Wright"), [Evanna
Lynch](/wiki/Evanna_Lynch "Evanna Lynch"), [Matthew
Lewis](/wiki/Matthew_Lewis_\(actor\) "Matthew Lewis \(actor\)"), [James and
Oliver Phelps](/wiki/James_and_Oliver_Phelps "James and Oliver Phelps"), [Tom
Felton](/wiki/Tom_Felton "Tom Felton"), [Robbie
Coltrane](/wiki/Robbie_Coltrane "Robbie Coltrane"), [Warwick
Davis](/wiki/Warwick_Davis "Warwick Davis") and [Helena Bonham
Carter](/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter "Helena Bonham Carter") attending. New
photos of Diagon Alley were later released the same night and the official
opening date was announced publicly by [Universal
Orlando](/wiki/Universal_Orlando "Universal Orlando")'s president, Bill
Davis.[55] King's Cross station opened on July 1, 2014, as well as the
[Hogwarts Express Hogsmeade
Station](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\) "Hogwarts Express
\(Universal Orlando Resort\)") at [Islands of
Adventure](/wiki/Islands_of_Adventure "Islands of Adventure") and soft
openings of Diagon Alley began on July 3, 2014.[5] Diagon Alley officially
opened on July 8, 2014.[6][7][8]

##
Rides[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Rides")]

The Wizarding World of Harry Potter has four rides. Three rides opened in 2010
as part of phase one. An additional two rides opened with phase two in 2014.

[![Entrance of Dragon
Challenge](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/DragonChallengeEntrance.JPG/220px-
DragonChallengeEntrance.JPG)](/wiki/File:DragonChallengeEntrance.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:DragonChallengeEntrance.JPG "Enlarge")

Entrance of Dragon Challenge, which has since been closed.

[Dragon Challenge](/wiki/Dragon_Challenge "Dragon Challenge") was a [roller
coaster](/wiki/Roller_coaster "Roller coaster") featuring two distinct tracks
built to overlap and intertwine with each other. The ride was formerly in
operation since the park's 1999 opening under the name [Dueling
Dragons](/wiki/Dueling_Dragons "Dueling Dragons"). The physical coaster is
exactly the same, with some new decor.[56] The attraction was renamed in
homage to the first task of the [Triwizard
Tournament](/wiki/Triwizard_Tournament "Triwizard Tournament") where Harry and
the other contestants are each to duel with a dragon, depicted in chapter 20
of _[Harry Potter and the Goblet of
Fire](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire "Harry Potter and the Goblet
of Fire")_.[57] The two sides of the coaster have been renamed "Hungarian
Horntail" and "Chinese Fireball",[56] after two of the dragon breeds which
appear in the book. It was the only chasing [inverted roller
coaster](/wiki/Inverted_roller_coaster "Inverted roller coaster") in the
world. The queue for this ride features many Harry Potter relics, including
the Goblet of Fire and the Triwizard Cup. In addition, the hike to the ride
features the flying car featured in the second film, as well as Hagrid's hut.
On July 24, 2017, Universal Orlando officials announced that Dragon Challenge
would close after September 4, 2017 to make way for a new attraction based on
the _Harry Potter_ franchise that is scheduled to open in 2019.[58][59][60]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Universal-Islands-of-
Adventure-Harry-Potter-Castle-9188.jpg/170px-Universal-Islands-of-Adventure-
Harry-Potter-Castle-9188.jpg)](/wiki/File:Universal-Islands-of-Adventure-
Harry-Potter-Castle-9188.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Universal-Islands-of-Adventure-Harry-Potter-Castle-9188.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Hogwarts Castle](/wiki/Hogwarts_Castle "Hogwarts Castle") exterior of _Harry
Potter and the Forbidden Journey_ as seen from the Herbology greenhouse queue

_[Harry Potter and the Forbidden
Journey](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Forbidden_Journey "Harry Potter and the
Forbidden Journey")_ is a new attraction inside the replica of [Hogwarts
Castle](/wiki/Hogwarts_Castle "Hogwarts Castle"), simulating a tour of the
castle and its surrounding grounds. Visitors initially walk through the
castle, interacting with various characters and props from the _Potter_
series,[61] including a speech from Dumbledore, and directions from Harry,
Hermione and Ron, before boarding a "magical bench" (controlled with a
[KUKA](/wiki/KUKA "KUKA") robotic arm system[62]). Throughout the ride, guests
are taken around the outside of the castle, using a combination of simulated
flight as well as encountering realistic animatronic versions of the [Whomping
Willow](/wiki/Whomping_Willow "Whomping Willow"), a horde of
[dementors](/wiki/Dementors "Dementors"), giant spiders, the Hungarian
Horntail Dragon, and a [Quidditch](/wiki/Quidditch "Quidditch") match.[63]

[Flight of the Hippogriff](/wiki/Flight_of_the_Hippogriff "Flight of the
Hippogriff") is a [steel roller coaster](/wiki/Steel_roller_coaster "Steel
roller coaster") designed for families, located adjacent to Harry Potter and
the Forbidden Journey. The ride opened in 2000 as the [Flying
Unicorn](/wiki/Flying_Unicorn "Flying Unicorn").[64] Similar to the Dragon
Challenge, this ride was re-themed prior to the opening of the Wizarding
World. The roller coaster's back-story is that Hogwarts's Care of Magical
Creatures professor, [Hagrid](/wiki/Hagrid "Hagrid"), is teaching young
wizards to fly on a [hippogriff](/wiki/Hippogriff "Hippogriff") (as Harry does
in _[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of
Azkaban](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban "Harry Potter and the
Prisoner of Azkaban")_) by using a wicker replica of the creature. A
recreation of Hagrid's Hut is passed on the way for a lesson from Hagrid
himself on how to properly approach a hippogriff.[65][66]

[![Gringotts Bank, which houses Harry Potter and the Escape from
Gringotts](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Diagon_Alley3.jpg/220px-
Diagon_Alley3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Diagon_Alley3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Diagon_Alley3.jpg "Enlarge")

Gringotts Bank, which houses _[Harry Potter and the Escape from
Gringotts](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Escape_from_Gringotts "Harry Potter and
the Escape from Gringotts")_

Diagon Alley's flagship attraction is [Harry Potter and the Escape from
Gringotts](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Escape_from_Gringotts "Harry Potter and
the Escape from Gringotts"), [3-D](/wiki/4D_film "4D film") [motion-
based](/wiki/Motion_simulator "Motion simulator") [steel roller
coaster](/wiki/Steel_roller_coaster "Steel roller coaster") [dark
ride](/wiki/Dark_ride "Dark ride") based around Gringotts Bank, the wizarding
bank in Diagon Alley.[67] Riders enter the bank into the queue area where
Bogrod greets visitors and instructs them to continue past him to travel deep
into the vaults of the bank to open an account. Unlike _[Harry Potter and the
Forbidden Journey](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Forbidden_Journey "Harry Potter
and the Forbidden Journey")_ , this ride is hosted by [Bill
Weasley](/wiki/Bill_Weasley "Bill Weasley"), played by [Domhnall
Gleeson](/wiki/Domhnall_Gleeson "Domhnall Gleeson"), reprising his role from
_[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part
1](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_1 "Harry Potter
and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1")_ and _[Part
2](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_2 "Harry Potter
and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2")_.

A completely functioning [full-scale replica of the Hogwarts
Express](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\) "Hogwarts Express
\(Universal Orlando Resort\)") was created for the Diagon Alley expansion,
connecting King's Cross Station at Universal Studios to the Hogsmeade station
at Islands of Adventure,[48][68] manufactured by [Doppelmayr Garaventa
Group](/wiki/Doppelmayr_Garaventa_Group "Doppelmayr Garaventa Group") in the
form of a [funicular](/wiki/Funicular "Funicular") railway [people
mover](/wiki/People_mover "People mover").[69] The Hogwarts Express King's
Cross Station features a wall between Platforms 9 and 10, where guests can
"walk through" to get to Platform 9¾, like in the first film.

## Dining, shopping, and other
attractions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Dining, shopping, and other attractions")]

[![Inside Ollivanders wand
shop](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/OllivandersInterior.JPG/220px-
OllivandersInterior.JPG)](/wiki/File:OllivandersInterior.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:OllivandersInterior.JPG "Enlarge")

Inside _Ollivanders_ wand shop

Other than the main rides, The Wizarding World of Harry Potter is also home to
gift shops, restaurants and other tourist attractions. Several of these are
recreations of locations in the Harry Potter books while others have been
created specifically for the park. A recreation of Hogsmeade is housed at
Islands of Adventure while a recreation of Diagon Alley is housed at Universal
Studios Florida.

In the book series, [Ollivanders wand shop](/wiki/Ollivanders "Ollivanders")
is located in [Diagon Alley](/wiki/Diagon_Alley "Diagon Alley"), not
[Hogsmeade](/wiki/Hogsmeade "Hogsmeade"); however, installations of the shop
are present in both areas of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter. The
Hogsmeade attraction recreated the shop as "Ollivanders", portraying it as a
[branch](/wiki/Branch_\(banking\) "Branch \(banking\)") of the original where
Harry purchases his [wand](/wiki/Wand "Wand") in _[Harry Potter and the
Philosopher's Stone](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone "Harry
Potter and the Philosopher's Stone")_ (known in the United States as _Harry
Potter and the Sorcerer 's Stone_). Unlike other shops in the Wizarding World
of Harry Potter, visitors are admitted in groups of 20 to experience the
premise from the _Potter_ series, that "the wand chooses the wizard". Similar
to the first film, the wand keeper and a selected guest test a variety of
wands until the right one is found. Effects include flowers drying out or a
thunderstorm erupting inside the shop. After experiencing the attraction,
souvenir wands can be purchased.[70]

###
Hogsmeade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Hogsmeade")]

[![A recreation of the Hogwarts
Express](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/HogwartsExpressUniversalStudios.JPG/220px-
HogwartsExpressUniversalStudios.JPG)](/wiki/File:HogwartsExpressUniversalStudios.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:HogwartsExpressUniversalStudios.JPG "Enlarge")

A recreation of the [Hogwarts Express](/wiki/GWR_4900_Class_5972_Olton_Hall
"GWR 4900 Class 5972 Olton Hall") locomotive greets guests when entering
Hogsmeade

A recreation of the _[Hogwarts Express](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express "Hogwarts
Express")_ lies at the entry to Hogsmeade. The recreation features "billowing
steam and an iconic whistle" and is accompanied by the conductor of the train.
In the _Harry Potter_ series the Hogwarts Express is the train used to
transport students from London to Hogwarts. The "Owl Post" is a working post
office (where postcards and letters will be delivered with an authentic
Hogsmeade postmark) that also sells stationery, writing implements, stamps,
and owl-related gifts.

[![Hogmeade](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter.jpg/240px-
The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter.jpg "Enlarge")

Hogsmeade village as seen from [Flight of the
Hippogriff](/wiki/Flight_of_the_Hippogriff "Flight of the Hippogriff")

"The Three Broomsticks", based on the [inn and pub from the _Harry Potter_
series](/wiki/The_Three_Broomsticks "The Three Broomsticks"), offers a variety
of food and beverage items from the Harry Potter universe, including
[Butterbeer](/wiki/Butterbeer "Butterbeer"), [pumpkin
juice](/wiki/Harry_Potter_universe#Pumpkin_juice "Harry Potter universe"),
strawberry-peanut butter ice cream (as seen in _[Harry Potter and the Prisoner
of Azkaban](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban "Harry Potter and
the Prisoner of Azkaban")_), and chocolate Cauldron Cakes, in addition to a
menu composed of traditional British fare ([Shepherd's
pie](/wiki/Shepherd%27s_pie "Shepherd's pie"), [fish and
chips](/wiki/Fish_and_chips "Fish and chips"), etc.). The pub features many
hidden references to the book, namely house elves and ghosts that roam the
rafters.[71][72] Butterbeer, which can be purchased with a souvenir mug, is
offered as a non-alcoholic beverage and comes in both regular and frozen
forms, found at the beginning of Hogsmeade fresh off the tap from the
butterbeer cart. Similarly, _The Hog 's Head_ is based on the [pub from the
_Harry Potter_ series](/wiki/The_Hog%27s_Head "The Hog's Head") owned by
[Aberforth Dumbledore](/wiki/Aberforth_Dumbledore "Aberforth
Dumbledore").[71][72] _Honeydukes_ is a sweet shop, based on [Honeydukes
Sweetshop](/wiki/Honeydukes "Honeydukes") in the _Harry Potter_ series. The
shop sells many items from the [Harry Potter
universe](/wiki/Harry_Potter_universe "Harry Potter universe") including
Chocolate Frogs, Acid Pops, exploding bonbons, Cauldron Cakes, treacle fudge,
Fizzing Whizzbees, Pepper Imps, and [Bertie Bott's Every Flavour
Beans](/wiki/Bertie_Bott%27s_Every_Flavour_Beans "Bertie Bott's Every Flavour
Beans").[73]

Various Harry Potter merchandise items can be purchased from two different
gift shops in Hogsmeade. Dervish and Banges is a store selling magical items,
as well as Quidditch supplies, Hogwarts clothing, and other merchandise. The
store is based on [Dervish and Banges](/wiki/Dervish_%26_Banges "Dervish &
Banges") in the _Harry Potter_ series.[74] The second shop is Filch's Emporium
of Confiscated Goods. It is a general gift shop (named for Hogwarts caretaker
[Argus Filch](/wiki/Argus_Filch "Argus Filch")) offering Hogwarts souvenirs
(such as clothing and stationery), replicas of
[props](/wiki/Theatrical_property "Theatrical property") from the _Harry
Potter_ films, and other toys and souvenirs. The shop is at the exit to Harry
Potter and the Forbidden Journey, and is where guests can obtain [photos of
their ride experience](/wiki/On-ride_photos "On-ride photos").[75]

### Diagon
Alley[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Diagon Alley")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Stairs_Diagon_Alley.JPG/170px-
Stairs_Diagon_Alley.JPG)](/wiki/File:Stairs_Diagon_Alley.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Stairs_Diagon_Alley.JPG "Enlarge")

Stairway located between the Magical Menagerie and Gringotts Bank

Live attractions at Diagon Alley include the [Knight Bus](/wiki/The_Knight_Bus
"The Knight Bus") interactive show at the London waterfront; "The Fountain of
Fair Fortune" and "The Tale of The Three Brothers," which are puppet shows
enacting stories from _[The Tales of Beedle the
Bard](/wiki/The_Tales_of_Beedle_the_Bard "The Tales of Beedle the Bard");_ and
live performances from musical group Celestina Warbeck and the Banshees
(mentioned briefly by [Molly Weasley](/wiki/Molly_Weasley "Molly Weasley") in
_[Harry Potter and the Chamber of
Secrets](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets "Harry Potter and the
Chamber of Secrets")_).

Gringotts Money Exchange is able to exchange American currency for Wizarding
bank notes. Diagon Alley features [The Leaky
Cauldron](/wiki/The_Leaky_Cauldron_\(pub\) "The Leaky Cauldron \(pub\)")
restaurant,[50] The Hopping Pot, and [Florean Fortescue's Ice Cream
Parlour](/wiki/Florean_Fortescue%27s_Ice_Cream_Parlour "Florean Fortescue's
Ice Cream Parlour"), which specializes in Butterbeer-flavored ice cream.[68]
The Fountain of Fair Fortune is also a bar. [Ollivander's Wand
Shop](/wiki/Ollivander%27s_Wand_Shop "Ollivander's Wand Shop") sells
interactive wands that activate features all around Diagon Alley, [Quality
Quidditch Supplies](/wiki/Quality_Quidditch_Supplies "Quality Quidditch
Supplies"), [Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes](/wiki/Weasleys%27_Wizard_Wheezes
"Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes") joke shop, [Magical
Menagerie](/wiki/Places_in_Harry_Potter#Magical_Menagerie "Places in Harry
Potter"), [Madam Malkin's Robes for All
Occasions](/wiki/Madam_Malkin%27s_Robes_for_All_Occasions "Madam Malkin's
Robes for All Occasions"), [Wiseacre's Wizarding
Equipment](/wiki/Wiseacre%27s_Wizarding_Equipment "Wiseacre's Wizarding
Equipment"). [Borgin and Burkes](/wiki/Borgin_and_Burkes "Borgin and Burkes")
is the only shop located in Knockturn Alley.

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_\(Universal_Orlando_Resort\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Reception")]

The Wizarding World of Harry Potter was well received by Harry Potter fans.
Matt Blum of _[Wired](/wiki/Wired_\(magazine\) "Wired \(magazine\)")_ stated
"every detail is finely crafted to enhance the experience".[76] An _Orlando
Sentinel_ article stated "muggles will love their Harry Potter adventure" but
identifies the need for the park to offer Universal Express Passes due to
large crowds. It also stated Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey is a truly
one-of-a-kind experience that cannot easily be described.[77] Lisa Minot, from
_The Sun_ , stated "after a sneak peek, I can say it is the most faithful
recreation of JK Rowling's books and movies ever seen. Fans will be in
heaven."[78] Leigh Caldwell from Traveling Mamas noted that although The
Wizarding World of Harry Potter is ideal for the whole family, it's not
designed for anyone under 3 years old." She went on to consolidate others'
comments about the area: "there is no doubt that fans of the Harry Potter
books and movies are going to enjoy the heck out of a visit to the Wizarding
World".[79] [Boris Johnson](/wiki/Boris_Johnson "Boris Johnson"), Mayor of
London, criticized the fact that the park was chosen to be in Orlando, rather
than in London, stating that it was "utterly mad" to leave it to the Americans
"to make money from a great British invention."[80]
